{{For|the various bands of the Blackfoot or Blackfeet people|Blackfoot (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox language | name = Blackfoot | nativename = ''Siksiká'' (ᓱᖽᐧᖿ) | states = [[Canada]], [[United States]] | region = [[Piikani Nation]], [[Siksika Nation]], and [[Kainai Nation]] in southern [[Alberta]]; [[Blackfeet Nation]] in [[Montana]] | ethnicity = 51,221 [[Blackfoot Confederacy|Blackfoot]]Simons & Fennig 2017, Ethnologue | speakers = 4,915, 10% of ethnic population | date = 2016 | familycolor = Algic | fam1 = [[Algic languages|Algic]] | fam2 = [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]] | fam3 = [[Plains Algonquian languages|Plains Algonquian]] | script = [[Canadian Aboriginal syllabics#Blackfoot|Blackfoot Syllabics]]
Sometimes Latin | nation = | iso2 = bla | iso3 = bla | notice = IPA | glotto = siks1238 | glottorefname = Siksika }} The '''Blackfoot language''', also called '''Siksiká''' (ᓱᖽᐧᖿ, its denomination in [[ISO 639-3]]), ({{IPAc-en|lang|pron|s|iː|k|ˈ|s|iː|k|ə}}; Siksiká [[Help:IPA|[siksiká]]], [[Blackfoot language#Writing system|syllabics]] {{lang|bla|'''ᓱᖽᐧᖿ'''}}), often anglicised as '''''{{lang|bla|Siksika}}''''', is an [[Algonquian languages|Algonquian]] language spoken by the [[Blackfoot Confederacy|Blackfoot]] or ''Niitsitapi'' people, who currently live in the northwestern plains of [[North America]]. There are four dialects, three of which are spoken in [[Alberta]], Canada, and one of which is spoken in the United States: ''Siksiká'' (Blackfoot), to the southeast of Calgary, Alberta; ''Kainai'' (Blood, Many Chiefs), spoken in Alberta between Cardston and Lethbridge; ''Aapátohsipikani'' (Northern Piegan), to the west of Fort MacLeod; and ''Aamsskáápipikani'' (Southern Piegan), in northwestern [[Montana]].Frantz "The Blackfoot Language" The name Blackfoot probably comes from the blackened soles of the leather shoes that the people wore.Gibson 2003 There is a distinct difference between Old Blackfoot (also called High Blackfoot), the dialect spoken by many older speakers, and New Blackfoot (also called Modern Blackfoot), the dialect spoken by younger speakers.Bortolin & McLennan 1995 Among the [[Algonquian languages]], Blackfoot is relatively divergent in phonology and lexicon.Mithun 1999, p. 335 The language has a fairly small phoneme inventory; consisting of 11 basic consonants and three basic vowels that have contrastive length counterparts. Blackfoot is a [[pitch accent]] language.{{Cite journal|last=Miyashita|first=Mizuki|last2=Fish|first2=Naatosi|date=12 Mar 2015|title=Documenting Blackfoot pitch excursion|url=https://scholarspace.manoa.hawaii.edu/handle/10125/25290|journal=|volume=|pages=|hdl=10125/25290}}Frantz 2017, p. 3 Blackfoot language has been declining in the number of native speakers and is classified as either a threatened or endangered language.{{Cite web|url=http://www.endangeredlanguages.com/lang/1677|title=Did you know Blackfoot is endangered?|website=Endangered Languages|language=en|access-date=2017-04-16}} Like the other Algonquian languages, Blackfoot is considered to be a [[polysynthetic language]] due to its large morpheme inventory and word internal complexity.Aikhenvald 2007, p. 5 A majority of Blackfoot morphemes have a one to one correspondence between form and meaning, a defining feature of [[agglutinative language]]s. However, Blackfoot does display some [[Fusional language|fusional]] characteristics as there are morphemes that are polysemous.Armoskaite 2011, p. 16 Both noun and verb stems cannot be used bare but must be inflected.Frantz 2017, p. 7 Due to its morphological complexity, Blackfoot has a flexible [[word order]]. == Classification == Blackfoot is a member of the Algonquian language belonging to the [[Plains Algonquian languages|Plains]] branch along with [[Arapaho language|Arapaho]], [[Gros Ventre language|Gros Ventre]], and [[Cheyenne language|Cheyenne]]. Blackfoot is spoken in Northwestern Montana and throughout Alberta, Canada, making it geographically one of the westernmost Algonquian languages. == History == Once, the Blackfoot people were one of a few Native American nations, that inhabited the Great Plains west of the Mississippi river. The people were buffalo hunters, with settlements in the northern United States. Forced to move because of wars with neighboring tribes, the Blackfoot people settled all around the plains area and up into Canada, eventually concentrating in Montana. Blackfoot hunters would track and hunt game, while the remaining people would gather food, and other necessities for the winter. The northern plains, where the Blackfoot settled, had incredibly harsh winters, and the flat land provided little escape from the winds. The Blackfoot Nation thrived, along with many other native groups, until the European settlers arrived in the late eighteenth century. The settlers brought with them horses and technology, but also disease and weapons. Diseases like smallpox, foreign to the natives, decimated the Blackfoot population in the mid-nineteenth century. Groups of Blackfoot people rebelled against the Europeans like Mountain Chief's tribe. But, in 1870, a tribe of peaceful Blackfoot were mistaken for the rebellious tribe and hundreds were slaughtered. Over the next thirty years, the settlers had eradicated the buffalo from the Great Plains. This took away the main element of Blackfoot life and took away the people's ability to be self-sustaining. With their main food source gone, the Blackfoot were forced to rely on government support. == Phonology == ===Consonants=== Blackfoot has eighteen consonants, of which all but {{IPA|/ʔ/}}, {{IPA|/x/}}, {{IPA|/j/}} and {{IPA|/w/}} form pairs distinguished by length.[http://www.native-languages.org/blackfoot_guide.htm "Blackfoot Pronunciation and Spelling Guide"]. Native-Languages.org. Retrieved 2007-04-10Frantz 1999 {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! ! colspan="2" |[[Labial consonant|Labial]] ! colspan="2" |[[Coronal consonant|Coronal]] ! colspan="2" |[[Dorsal consonant|Dorsal]] ![[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ![[Nasal consonant|Nasal]] | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|m}} | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|mː}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|n}} | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|nː}} | colspan="2" | | |- ![[Plosive consonant|Plosive]] | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|p}} | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|pː}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|t}} | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|tː}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|k}} | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|kː}} |{{IPA|ʔ}} |- ![[Affricate consonant|Affricate]] | colspan="2" | | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|t͡s}} | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|t͡sː}} | colspan="2" | | |- ![[Fricative consonant|Fricative]] | colspan="2" | | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|s}} | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|sː}} | colspan="2" |{{IPA|x}} | |- ![[Approximant consonant|Approximant]] | colspan="2" |{{IPA|w}} | colspan="2" | | colspan="2" |{{IPA|j}} | |} ===Vowels=== ==== Monophthongs ==== Blackfoot has a vowel system with three [[monophthong]]s, {{IPA|/i o a/}}.Frantz 2017, pp. 1–2 {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! ! colspan="2" |[[Front vowel|Front]] ! colspan="2" |[[Central vowel|Central]] ! colspan="2" |[[Back vowel|Back]] |- ![[Close vowel|High]] | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|i}} | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|iː}} | colspan="2" | | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|o}} | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|oː}} |- ![[Open vowel|Low]] | colspan="2" | | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|a}} | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|aː}} | colspan="2" | |} The short [[monophthong]]s exhibit [[Allophone|allophonic]] changes as well. The vowels {{IPA|/a/}} and {{IPA|/o/}} are raised to {{IPA|[ʌ]}} and {{IPA|[ʊ]}} respectively when followed by a long consonant. The vowel /i/ becomes {{IPA|[ɪ]}} in closed syllables. ==== Diphthongs ==== There are three additional [[diphthong]]s in Blackfoot. The first diphthong '''ai''' is pronounced {{IPA|[ɛ]}} before a long consonant, {{IPA|[ei]}} (or {{IPA|[ai]}}, in the dialect of the Blackfoot Reserve) before {{IPA|/i/}} or {{IPA|/ʔ/}}, and elsewhere is pronounced {{IPA|[æ]}} in the Blood Reserve dialect or {{IPA|[ei]}} in the Blackfoot Reserve dialect. The second diphthong '''ao''' is pronounced {{IPA|[au]}} before {{IPA|/ʔ/}} and {{IPA|[ɔ]}} elsewhere. The third diphthong '''oi''' may be pronounced [y] before a long consonant and as {{IPA|/oi/}} elsewhere .Frantz 2017, p. 2 === Length === [[Vowel length|Length]] is contrastive in Blackfoot for both vowels and consonants. Vowel length refers to the duration of a vowel and not a change in quality. The vowel /oo/ is therefore the same sound as /o/ only differing in the length of time over which it is produced. : {| |''áak'''o'''kaawa'' | | |'he will rope' |- |''áak'''oo'''kaawa'' | | |'she will sponsor a Sundance' |} Consonants can also be lengthened with the exception of {{IPA|/ʔ/}}, {{IPA|/x/}}, {{IPA|/j/}} and {{IPA|/w/}}. : {| |''kiipí'''pp'''o'' | | |'one hundred' |- |''ní'''nn'''a'' | | |'my father' |- |''soká'p'''ss'''iwa'' | | |'he is good' |} === Pitch accent === Blackfoot is a [[pitch accent]] language and it is a contrastive feature in the language. Every word will have at least one high pitched vowel or diphthong but may have more than one. Note that high pitch here is used relative to the contiguous syllables. Blackfoot utterances experience a gradual drop in pitch therefore if an utterance contains a set of accented vowels the first will be higher in pitch than the second but the second will be higher in pitch than the syllables directly surrounding it. Pitch is illustrated in the Latin-based orthography with an acute accent. : {| |''ápssiwa'' | | |'it's an arrow' |- |''apssíwa'' | | |'it's a fig' |- |''máátaissikópiiwa'' | | |'s/he's not resting' |} === Phonological rules === Blackfoot is rich with morpho-phonological changes. Below is a limited sample of phonological rules. ==== Semi-vowel loss ==== Glides are deleted after another consonant, except a glottal stop, or word initially but kept in other conditions.Frantz 2017, p. 155 : {| | |/w/ loss | |- |''poos-wa'' !→ |''póósa'' |- |cat-AN.SG | |'cat' |- | |/y/ loss | |- |''óóhkotok-yi'' !→ |''óóhkotoki'' |- |stone-IN.SG | |'stone' |- | |word initial | |- |''w-óko'si'' !→ |''óko'si'' |- |3.SG.POSS-child | |'his/her child' |} ==== Accent spread ==== Accent will spread from an accented vowel to the following vowel across morpheme boundaries.Frantz 2017, p. 157 : {| |''á-okska'siwa'' |→ |''áókska'siwa'' | | |'s/he runs' |- |''atsikí-istsi'' |→ |''atsikíístsi'' | | |'shoes' |} ==== Vowel devoicing ==== At the end of a word, non-high pitched vowels are devoiced, regardless of length.Frantz 2017, p. 5 ==Grammar – general== ===Lexical categories=== Lexical categories in Blackfoot are a matter of debate in the literature, with the exception of nouns and verbs. Additional proposed categories, proposed by Uhlenbeck, are adjectives, pronouns, adverbs, and particles.Uhlenbeck (1938) Taylor classifies the Blackfoot language as having two major classes, substantives (nouns and pronouns) and verbs, with one minor class consisting of particles.Taylor (1953) Frantz classifies adjectives and adverbs as affixes but not independent classes.Frantz 2017, p. 23 === Agreement === Agreement morphology is extensive in Blackfoot and agreement morphemes are often polysemous, i.e. animacy and number (nouns) or person and number (verbs) are indicated within the same affix. ====Animacy==== All nouns are required to be inflected for animacy and are classified as either animate or inanimate. Verbs are inflected to match the animacy of its arguments. Animacy in Blackfoot is a grammatical construct for noun classification. Therefore, some semantically inherently inanimate objects, such as drums and knives are grammatically animate.Frantz 2017, pp. 7–10 Verbs are marked with a transitivity marker which must agree with the animacy of its arguments. Even in stories in which a grammatically inanimate object are markedly anthropomorphized, such as talking flowers, speakers will not use animate agreement markers with them. ==== Number ==== All nouns are required to be inflected as either singular or plural. Verbal inflection matches the plurality of its arguments. ==== Person marking ==== Blackfoot has five grammatical persons – first, second, third (proximate), fourth (obviative), and fifth (sub-obviative).{{Cite journal|last=Frantz|first=Donald G.|date=1966-01-01|title=Person Indexing in Blackfoot|jstor=1263448|journal=International Journal of American Linguistics|volume=32|issue=1|pages=50–58|doi=10.1086/464879}} === Word order === Word order is flexible in Blackfoot. Subjects are not required to precede the verb.Frantz 2017, p. 20 Independent noun phrases may be included but these are typically dropped in Blackfoot due to the extensive person inflection on the verb they aren't necessary to interpret the meaning of the utterance. However, if first or second person pronouns are present it yields an emphatic reading.Frantz 2017, p. 22 There is an ordering restriction if the Distinct Third Person (DTP) attached pronoun /-aawa/ is used in which the subject independent noun phrase must occur before the verb. If the independent noun phrase occurs after the verb then the DTP may not be used.Frantz 2017, pp. 48–49 === Subjecthood === Blackfoot nouns must be grammatically particular in order to be a subject of a verb. In transitive constructions the subject must be volitional to be interpreted as subject.Frantz 2017, pp. 45–46 === Person hierarchy === It has been asserted that Blackfoot, along with other Algonquian languages violates the Universal Person Hierarchy in verb complexes by ranking second person over first person. The hierarchy has traditionally been published as 2nd person > 1st person > 3rd person (proximate) > 4th person (obviative).{{Cite journal|last=Russell|first=Lena|last2=Genee|first2=Inge|last3=Lier|first3=Eva van|last4=Zúñiga|first4=Fernando|title=Referential Hierarchies in Three-Participant Constructions in Blackfoot: The Effects of Animacy, Person, and Specificity|url=http://journals.dartmouth.edu/cgi-bin/WebObjects/Journals.woa/xmlpage/1/article/416|journal=Linguistic Discovery|volume=10|issue=3|doi=10.1349/ps1.1537-0852.a.416|year=2012}} However, alternative analyses of Blackfoot person hierarchy has been published that suggest the Universal Person Hierarchy is applicable to Blackfoot.{{Cite journal|last=Bliss|first=Heather|last2=Jesney|first2=Karen|date=May 2005|title=Resolving hierarchy conflict: local obviation in Blackfoot*|url=http://hdl.handle.net/1880/51468|journal=Calgary Working Papers in Linguistics|volume=26|pages=92–116}} ===Verbal structure=== The Blackfoot verbal template contains a stem with several prefixes and suffixes. The structure of the verb stem in Blackfoot can be roughly broken down into the pre-verb, the root, the medial, and the final. The root and final are required elements. Generally, information encoded in the pre-verb can include adverbs, most pronouns, locatives, manners, aspect, mood, and tense. Incorporated objects appear in the medial. The final includes transitivity and animacy markers, and valency markers. == Grammar – nouns == === Agreement morphology === Noun classes are split based on [[grammatical gender]] into two categories: animate and inanimate.Frantz 2017, p. 8 Additionally, all nouns must be marked for plurality. Plurality agreement are suffixes that attach to noun stems and take four forms, as shown in the table below. :{| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" |Inanimate ! rowspan="3" | ! colspan="2" |Animate |- |Singular |Plural |Singular |Plural |- | ''-yi'' | ''-istsi'' | ''-wa'' | ''-iksi'' |} :{| | colspan="3" |''í'ksisako'' (inanimate stem) | | |'meat' |- |''í'ksisako-yi'' |→ |''í'ksisakoyi'' ||| ||'meat' |- |''í'ksisako-istsi'' |→ |''í'ksisakoistsi'' ||||||''meats' |} === Proximate and obviative === When a sentence contains two or more particular animate gender nouns as arguments proximate (major third person/3rd) and obviative (minor third person/4th) markings are used to disambiguate. There may only be one proximate argument in any given sentence but multiple obviates are permissible. Proximate arguments are more prominent in discourse. Redirectional markers, referred to as inverse and direct theme in the literature, can be applied to indicate that the fourth person is the subject argument.Frantz 2017, pp. 13–14 === Particularity/referentiality === Blackfoot nouns must be grammatically particular, according to Frantz (2009), in order to be a subject of a verb. To be the subject of any verb in Blackfoot the noun must point to a specific referent in the world. In transitive constructions the subject must also be volitional to be interpreted as subject. If subject of a transitive verb is non-specific or non-volitional then verb must be inflected as having an unspecified subject.Frantz 2017, p. 12 :{| |Oma |isttoána |iihtsíkahksinii'pi |annistsi |ikkstsíksiistsi. |- |om-wa |isttoan-wa |iiht-íkahksinii-'p-yi |ann-istsi |ikkstsíksi-istsi |- |that-AN.SG |knife-AN.SG |means-cut.off-UNSPEC.SUB-IN.PL |that-IN.PL |branch-IN.PL |- | colspan="2" |`The knife cut off those branches.' | | | |- | colspan="2" |`By means of the knife, the branches were cut off.' | | | |} == Grammar – verbs == === Verbal morphology template === There are four verb categories in Blackfoot: intransitive inanimate, intransitive animate, transitive inanimate, and transitive animate. The parameters of transitivity and animacy for verb selection are typically referred to as stem agreement in order to delineate it from person agreement. The animacy for intransitive verbs is determined by the subject of the verb whereas the transitive verbs are defined by the animacy of their primary object.Frantz 2017, p. 40 The only required component of a clause in Blackfoot is the verb, referred to as a verbal complex in the Algonquian literature, that must be appropriately inflected according to the standard template:
preverb – root – medial – final
Preverbs are prefixes which encode adverbs, most pronouns, locatives, manners, aspect, mood, and tense. Medials are suffixes which primarily encode manner and incorporated objects. Finals are suffixes which encode transitivity, animacy, and valency. Roots and finals are always required in a verbal complex whereas preverb and medials are not.Armoskaite 2011, p. 22 === Inverse and direct theme === When there are two animate arguments acting in a transitive animate verb stem one of the arguments must be acting on the other. Which argument is the actor (subject) and which is the acted upon (object) is indicated by the use of direct or inverse theme marking. If a subject argument is higher than the object argument on the person hierarchy then the direct suffix is used. Conversely, when an object outranks the sentences subject then the inverse suffix is used.Frantz 2017, p. 56 :{| ! colspan="2" |Direct |- |Nitsikákomimmayi |nitániksi. |- |nit-ikákomimm-aa-yi |ni-táni-iksi |- |1.SG-love-DIR-3.PL |1.POSS-daughter-AN.PL |- |'I love my daughters.' | |} :{| ! colspan="2" |Inverse |- |Nitsikákomimmoki |nitániksi. |- |nit-ikákomimm-ok-yi |ni-táni-iksi |- |1.SG-love-INV-3.PL |1.POSS-daughter-AN.PL |- |'My daughters love me.' | |} === Voice and valency === Blackfoot voice alterations occur as suffixes on the verb and fall into the category of finals. Finals can include causative, benefactive, reciprocal, and reflexive affixes that either decrease or increase the valency of the stem they are attached too. Below is an example of the reflexive final suffix. It can only be added to a transitive animate stem and results in an animate intranstive stem. This is then interpreted as being a reflexive verb, where the subject of the AI stem is understood to be the both the underlying subject and object of the original verb stem.Frantz 2017, pp. 100–107 :{| |oma |imitááwa |siiksípohsiwa | |- |om-wa |imitáá-wa |siiksip-o:hsi-wa | |- |that-AN.SG |dog-AN.SG |PST:bite(TA)-REFL(AI)-3.SG | |- |‘That dog bit itself.’ | | | |} === Relative clauses === Relative clauses are rare in Blackfoot but they do occur. In order to embed a clause you first need to nominalize the clause. The reclassification strategy for nominalization is displayed here followed by a relative clause that uses a nominal formed by this strategy. Reclassification is done by adding nominal inflection to the verb stem instead of person inflection. This derived form then refers to the underlying subject and agrees in both number and animacy.Frantz 2017, pp. 114–129 :{| |omiksi |áyo'kaiksi/ |- |om-iksi |á-yo'kaa-iksi |- |that-AN.PL |DUR-sleep-AN.PL |- | colspan="2" |'those sleeping ones' |} Examples below show how a reclassifation nominalized clause is used in a relative clause. Note the nominal agreement morphology on the verb matches the subject, singular and plural, respectively. :{| |oma |nínaawa |áyo'kaawa |nóoma. |- |om-wa |ninaa-wa |á-yo'kaa-wa |n-oom-wa |- |that-AN.SG |man-AN.SG |DUR-sleep-AN.SG |1.POSS-husband-AN.SG |- | colspan="3" |'That man who is sleeping is my husband.' | |} :{| ! ! ! ! |- |Omiksi |aakííkoaiksi |áínihkiiksi |áyaakahkayiyaawa. |- |om-iks |aakííkoaN-iksi |á-Inihki-iksi |áyaak-wa:hkayi-yi-aawa |- |that-AN.PL |girl-AN.PL |DUR-sing-AN.PL |FUT-go.home-3.PL-PRO |- | colspan="3" |`Those girls who are singing are on their way home.' | |} ==Orthography{{anchor|Writing System}}== ===Latin-based orthography=== The Siksiká, Kainai, and Aapátohsipikani reserves adopted a standardized roman-based orthography in 1975. The Blackfoot alphabet consists of 13 letters.Frantz 2017, p. 163 {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! colspan="1" |[[Orthography]] ! colspan="1" |[[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] ! colspan="3" | ! colspan="1" |[[Orthography]] ! colspan="1" |[[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]] |- | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|m}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|m}} | colspan="3" | | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|'}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|ʔ}} |- | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|n}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|n}} | colspan="3" | | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|y}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|j}} |- | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|p}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|p}} | colspan="3" | | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|w}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|w}} |- | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|t}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|t}} | colspan="3" | | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|a}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|a}} |- | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|k}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|k}} | colspan="3" | | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|i}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|i}} |- | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|ts}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|t͡s}} | colspan="3" | | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|o}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|o}} |- | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|ks}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|k͡s}} | colspan="3" | | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|ai}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|æ}} |- | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|s}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|s}} | colspan="3" | | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|ao}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|ɔ}} |- | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|h}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|x}} | colspan="3" | | style="border-left:0" |{{IPA|}} | style="border-right:0" |{{IPA|}} |} Vowels can be marked with an acute accent or underlined to illustrate pitch accent. Vowels and consonants that are long are written with a double letter (aa = a:). ===Syllabic Writing System=== A [[Canadian Aboriginal syllabics|syllabics]] script, ᑯᖾᖹ ᖿᐟᖻ ᓱᖽᐧᖿ ''pikoni kayna siksika,'' was created by Anglican missionary [[John William Tims]] around 1888. Although conceptually nearly identical to [[Western Cree syllabics]], the letter forms are innovative. Two series ''(s, y)'' were taken from Cree but given different vowel values; three more ''(p, t, m)'' were changed in consonant values as well, according to the Latin letter they resembled; and the others ''(k, n, w)'' were created from asymmetrical parts of Latin and Greek letters; or in the case of the [[zero consonant]], possibly from the musical notation for [[quarter note]]. The Latin orientation of the letters is used for the ''e'' series, after the names of the Latin letters, ''pe, te,'' etc. {|class=wikitable !Blackfoot!!Latin source |- | ᑭ ''pe'' || '''P''' |- | ᒥ ''te'' || '''T''' |- | ᖼ ''ke'' || '''K''' |- | ᒋ ''me'' || '''m''' |- | ᖸ ''ne'' || '''N''' |- | ᖴ ''we'' || [[digamma]] '''Ϝ''' |} The direction for each vowel is different from Cree, reflecting Latin alphabetic order. The ''e'' orientation is used for the diphthong {{IPA|/ai/}}. Symbols for consonants are taken from the consonant symbol minus the stem, except for diphthongs (''Ca'' plus {{angle bracket|ᐠ}} for ''Cau'', and ''Ca'' plus {{angle bracket|ᐟ}} for ''Coi'', though there are also cases of writing subphonemic {{IPA|[ai, ei, eu]}} with these finals). {| class=wikitable ! C !! -a !! -e !! -i !! -o !! final || medial |- align=center | (none) || ᖳ || ᖰ || ᖱ || ᖲ || || |- align=center | align=left |  '''p-''' || ᑫ || ᑭ || ᑯ || ᑲ || ᐤ || |- align=center | align=left |  '''t-''' || ᒣ || ᒥ || ᒧ || ᒪ || ᐨ || |- align=center | align=left |  '''k-''' || ᖿ || ᖼ || ᖽ || ᖾ || ᘁ || |- align=center | align=left |  '''m-''' || ᒉ || ᒋ || ᒍ || ᒐ || ᐢ || |- align=center | align=left |  '''n-''' || ᖻ || ᖸ || ᖹ || ᖺ || ᐡ || |- align=center | align=left |  '''s-''' || ᓭ || ᓯ || ᓱ || ᓴ || ᔈ || ᐧ |- align=center | align=left |  '''y-''' || ᔦ || ᔨ || ᔪ || ᔭ || ᐟ || ᑉ |- align=center | align=left |  '''w-''' || ᖷ || ᖴ || ᖵ || ᖶ || ᐠ || ᙾ |} There are additional finals: allophones {{angle bracket|ᑊ}} {{IPA|[h]}} and {{angle bracket|ᐦ}} {{IPA|[x]}}, and three medials: {{angle bracket|ᖿᐧ}} ''ksa'', {{angle bracket|ᒣᐧ}} ''tsa'', {{angle bracket|ᖿᑉ}} ''kya'', {{angle bracket|ᖿᙾ}} ''kwa''. {{angle bracket|᙮}} is used for a period. Also sometimes it is written in Latin letters but with different spelling on computers because not all computers support the letters used in the Blackfoot language.{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} == Revitalization efforts == In the late 1900s,{{clarify|date=September 2014}} many tribes began a surge of revitalization efforts to encourage cultural awareness of indigenous customs and traditions. Of these, the Blackfoot revitalization effort has proven to be quite successful, producing various institutions, including a college dedicated to preserving and promoting Blackfoot traditions. Today, there are head-start programs in primary and secondary schools on the reservation to teach even infants and toddlers about the history of the tribe from an early age. === The Piegan Institute === In 1987, Dorothy Still Smoking and Darrell Robes Kipp founded the Piegan Institute,{{cite web |url=https://www.pieganinstitute.org |title=The Piegan Institute}} a private 501 c 3 non-profit foundation in Montana dedicated to researching, promoting, and preserving the Native American Languages, particularly the Blackfoot language. Piegan Institute founded Nizipuhwahsin (also Nizi Puh Wah Sin or Niitsípuwahsin or Cuts Wood) School in 1995 as a Blackfoot language K–8 immersion school. Since its inception the school has grown and relocated to the center of Browning, Montana in a custom built school house. Recently, some of the school's first graduates have returned to teach the newest generation the Blackfeet language.{{Cite web|url=http://www.pieganinstitute.org/community.html|title=Cuts Wood Academy – Blackfoot Immersion School in Browning, Montana|work=The Piegan Institute|accessdate=2014-04-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413144251/http://www.pieganinstitute.org/community.html|archive-date=2014-04-13|dead-url=yes|df=}} === Blackfoot Community College === Blackfoot Community College (BCC), founded in 1974, is a two-year, nationally accredited college that was made possible by the Indian Education Act of 1972 and the 1964 Act enacted by the Office of Economic Opportunity. BCC is a member of both the American Indian Higher Education Consortium and the American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES). It allows teenagers and adults alike to take classes in a wide range of subjects, from classes in Psychology and Digital Photography to classes on Blackfoot language and tradition. They have beginning Blackfoot language classes with labs for members and non-members of the community to learn the language.{{Cite book|title=The Blackfoot Papers|last=Hungry-wolf|first=Adolf|publisher=Good Medicine Cultural Foundation|year=2006|isbn=|location=|pages=195}} === Chief Mountain Technologies === In order to create jobs for the Blackfoot people with real-world applications, the Blackfeet Tribal Business Council launched a company called Chief Mountain Technologies in 2009. This company gives tribal members the opportunity to work in the fields of computer science and business in Browning, Montana on behalf of various government organizations. The establishment of this company in the Blackfoot community allows the people to use their culture and their language in the modern world while maintaining their traditions.{{Cite book|title=Blackfoot history and culture|last=Stout|first=Mary|date=2012|publisher=Gareth Stevens Pub|isbn=9781433959561|oclc=698361313}} ===Radio programming in Blackfoot=== Radio station KBWG in [[Browning, Montana]], broadcasts a one-hour show for Blackfoot language learners four times a week.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kfbb.com/news/local/KBWG-Brings-Blackfoot-Language-to-Airwaves-119887639.html|title=KBWG Brings Blackfoot Language Lessons to the Airwaves|last=Stephanie Tyrpak|date=2011-04-14|work=KFBB.com|accessdate=2012-09-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110419103436/http://www.kfbb.com/news/local/KBWG-Brings-Blackfoot-Language-to-Airwaves-119887639.html|archivedate=2011-04-19|df=}} The Voice of Browning, Thunder Radio, FM 107.5, or "Ksistsikam ayikinaan" (literally "voice from nowhere") went live in 2010, and focuses on positive programming. In 2011, John Davis, a 21-year-old [[Blackfeet Community College]] student explained "I was the first Blackfeet to ever talk on this radio", Davis said. "This is my [[Counting coup|coup story]]." A story in the [[Great Falls Tribune]] noted, "When the station was replaying programming that originated elsewhere, the radio was all '[[There's a Tear in My Beer|tear in my beer]]' and '[[Your Cheatin' Heart (Hank Williams, Jr. album)|your cheatin' heart]].' They called it the suicide station for its depressing old country themes ..." The station's offerings have now expanded beyond country to include AC/DC and Marvin Gaye, and "on-the-air jokes they would never hear on a [[Clear Channel Communications|Clear Channel]] radio station, such as: 'The captain is as cool as [[Government cheese|commodity cheese]].{{'"}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.browningmontana.com/kbwg107.5fm.html|title=KBWG, the 'Voice of Browning Montana' can be heard at 107.5 FM|date=2011-06-11|accessdate=2012-09-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120401203332/http://www.browningmontana.com/kbwg107.5fm.html|archivedate=2012-04-01|df=}} "So far we have broadcasting Monday through Friday from around 6:30, Indian time", quipped station manager Lona Burns, "to around 11, Indian time." ... "It's Indian radio", agreed Running Crane. "Where else can you hear today's hits with [[Native American music|traditional music]]?"{{Cite news|url=http://cutbankpioneerpress.com/articles/2011/01/19/glacier_reporter/news/doc4d371404bb7cd944393828.txt|title='Voice of Browning' radio station KBWG expanding|last=John McGill|date=2011-01-19|work=Glacier Reporter|accessdate=2012-09-09}} ===Canadian government support{{anchor|Writing System}}=== The Canadian government has provided support for the languages through funds and other financial resources. According to James Moore, the former Minister of Canadian Heritage and Official Languages, "the Government of Canada is committed to the revitalization and preservation of Aboriginal languages." The funding was put to use in the form of digital libraries containing interviews with native speakers, online courses, and various other resources in the hopes of promoting Blackfoot language and passing it down to subsequent generations. On top of both of these government efforts, the Canadian Government has also provided over $40,000 through the Aboriginal Languages Initiative Fund to promote the use of Aboriginal languages in community and family settings.Market Wired{{full citation needed|date=December 2014}} == References == {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite journal|last1=Baldwin|first1=S. {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox video game | title = Conker: Live & Reloaded | image = Conker - Live & Reloaded Coverart.png | developer = [[Rare (company)|Rare]] | publisher = [[Microsoft Studios|Microsoft Game Studios]] | director = | producer = | designer = Chris Seavor | programmer = Chris Marlow | artist = Stephen McFarlane
Louise Ridgeway | writer = | composer = [[Robin Beanland]] | series = ''[[Conker (series)|Conker]]'' | platforms = [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] | released = {{Video game release|NA|21 June 2005|EU|24 June 2005}} | genre = [[Platform game|Platform]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] }} '''''Conker: Live & Reloaded''''' is a [[Platform game|platform]] [[video game]] developed by [[Rare (company)|Rare]] and exclusively released for the [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] in June 2005. The single player mode is a [[Video game remake|remake]] of the 2001 game ''[[Conker's Bad Fur Day]]'' for the [[Nintendo 64]]. However, it includes a new multiplayer mode that is different from the Nintendo 64 version using [[Xbox Live]]. Development started the moment the studio was bought by Microsoft in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.rare-extreme.com/?section=conkerreload&page=conkerinterview.html |title=Interview with Chris Savor: The Voice of Conker at Rare-Extreme |publisher=rare-extreme.com |accessdate=31 May 2016 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019002449/http://www.rare-extreme.com/?section=conkerreload&page=conkerinterview.html |archivedate=19 October 2007 }} Recently of 2018, ''Live & Reloaded'' was made backwards-compatible with the [[Xbox One]]. It was also added onto the [[Microsoft Store (digital)|Microsoft Store]] as a digital copy. ==Multiplayer and gameplay== The Multiplayer in ''Live & Reloaded'' uses the same third-person perspective as the single-player game. Multiplayer consists of different game modes such as Capture the Flag or the standard Deathmatch modes. The player may participate as a member of the SHC or the Tediz. As well as a choice of soldier, the game has a choice of "classes" which significantly affect play style. Each class has its own special equipment, special abilities, and physical capabilities, each being designed for a distinct purpose. They are also designed to have advantages against certain classes while being vulnerable to others. For example, the Thermophile's [[flamethrower]] inflicts extreme damage on {{not a typo|Sneeker}}s and Long Rangers, who have less health, but is virtually useless against the high-vitality Demolisher. Each class comes equipped with a primary weapon with unlimited [[ammunition]] (although reloading of the weapon is still required), a limited stock of [[grenade]]s, and at least one special ability. Each class can also choose from several specialist ordnance items and vehicles unique to the class, which can be obtained at stations in team bases (however, an option is available to the host of a server to disable one or both features). Abilities common to all classes are the ability to shoulder all weapons for extra running speed, and a [[spray paint|Spray Can]] that can be used to apply the player's [[Graffiti#Styles|avatar image]] to walls to mock human opponents. Scattered throughout the arenas are yellow Upgrade Orbs, which grant a player more equipment and abilities when obtained. A player loses his upgrade orb upon death, allowing another player to obtain it. Terminals are found in every mission, usually near a base. Terminals are computers that dispense useful items or vehicles, and can be accessed by a player during the game. When accessed, the player is given a menu of the available items. When an item is chosen it can be picked up at an adjacent dispenser area. The objects received from the terminals disappear upon the death of the player that obtained them. Terminals may be neutral and available to both sides, or under the control of one side. Terminals can be attacked and disabled, but not destroyed. If damaged or disabled, they can be repaired with an arc weld, issued to the Demolisher and Sky Jockey classes. Neutral or enemy-controlled terminals can be hacked with a {{not a typo|Sneeker}}'s hacking device. There are two types of terminals: Specialist Ordinance terminals, and Mobile Units terminals. ==Censorship== The game was originally titled ''Conker: Live and Uncut'' and was to feature a completely uncensored single player experience. At some point during the development of the game, this was changed and the game was released with some censorship.{{cite web | url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2005/04/12/conker-playing-with-yourself | title = Conker: Playing with Yourself | publisher = IGN | date = 12 April 2005 | first = Hilary | last = Goldstein}} The censorship included that of some obscenities which were present in the original N64 version. This drew criticism from fans of the original, especially as it detracted from comedic highlights such as the "Great Mighty Poo" song in the ''Sloprano'' chapter. This song was also censored on the soundtrack, and Rare once had the uncensored Xbox version of the song on their website. Like the original, the game was rated M by the [[Entertainment Software Rating Board|ESRB]] and carried warnings about its content as well as Rare's promotional spoof warnings that advertised the fact that the content of the game was explicitly 'adult'. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews |MC = 78/100{{cite web|accessdate=9 June 2011 |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox/conker-live-reloaded |title=Conker: Live & Reloaded for Xbox Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]]}} |Edge = 8/10{{cite journal | title = Conker: Live & Reloaded | magazine = [[Edge (magazine)|Edge]] | issue = 152 | date = August 2005 | page = 93 | author = Edge staff}} |EGM = 6.67/10{{cite journal | title = Conker: Live & Reloaded | magazine = [[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] | issue = 194 | date = August 2005 | page = 115 | author = EGM staff}} |EuroG = 4/10{{cite web | url = http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/ss_conkerlive_x | title = Conker: Live & Reloaded Review | publisher = [[Eurogamer]] | accessdate = 4 January 2014 | date = 27 July 2005 | first = Kristan | last = Reed}} |Fam = 28/40{{cite web | url = http://www.neogaf.com/forum/showthread.php?t=52724 | title = this week Famitsu Reviews | publisher = [[NeoGAF]] | accessdate = 28 January 2016 | date = 22 June 2005 | author = Khalid-S}} |GI = 8/10{{cite journal | url = http://gameinformer.com/Games/Review/200508/R05.0819.1909.37588.htm | title = Conker: Live & Reloaded | magazine = [[Game Informer]] | accessdate = 4 January 2014 | issue = 148 | date = August 2005 | page = 103 | first = Andrew | last = Reiner | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090704120544/http://gameinformer.com/Games/Review/200508/R05.0819.1909.37588.htm | archivedate = 4 July 2009 | deadurl = yes}} |GameRev = B{{cite web | url = http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/conker058-live-a | title = Conker: Live and Reloaded Review | publisher = [[Game Revolution]] | accessdate = 4 January 2014 | date = 23 June 2005 | first = Joe | last = Dodson}} |GSpot = 8.3/10{{cite web | url = http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/conker-live-and-reloaded-review/1900-6127842/ | title = Conker: Live and Reloaded Review | publisher = [[GameSpot]] | first = Alex | last = Navarro | date = 21 June 2005 | accessdate = 3 January 2014}} |GSpy = {{Rating|4|5}} |GameZone = 9/10{{cite web | url = http://xbox.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r22280.htm | title = Conker: Live and Reloaded Review - Xbox | publisher = GameZone | accessdate = 3 January 2014 | date = 21 June 2005 | first = Steven | last = Hopper | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080225205942/http://xbox.gamezone.com/gzreviews/r22280.htm | archivedate = 25 February 2008 | deadurl = yes}} |IGN = 8.1/10{{cite web | url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2005/06/17/conker-live-and-reloaded | title = Conker: Live and Reloaded | publisher = [[IGN]] | accessdate = 3 January 2014 | date = 17 June 2005 | first = Hilary | last = Goldstein}} |OXM = 8/10{{cite journal | title = Review: Conker: Live and Reloaded | magazine = [[Official Xbox Magazine]] | date = August 2005 | page = 82}} |rev1 = ''[[Detroit Free Press]]'' |rev1Score = {{Rating|3|4}}{{cite web | url = http://www.freep.com/entertainment/videogames/game10e_20050710.htm | title = Online 'Conker' challenges multiplayers | publisher = ''[[Detroit Free Press]]'' | accessdate = 3 January 2014 | date = 10 July 2005 | first = Jim | last = Schaefer | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050712013328/http://www.freep.com/entertainment/videogames/game10e_20050710.htm | archivedate = 12 July 2005 | deadurl = yes}} |rev2 = ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' |rev2Score = {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite web | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/games/battling-on/2005/07/12/1120934248755.html | title = Battling on | publisher = ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' | accessdate = 3 January 2014 | date = 14 July 2005 | first = Jason | last = Hill}} }} ''Conker: Live & Reloaded'' was received positively by critics for its presentation and graphics.{{cite web | url = http://xbox.gamespy.com/xbox/conker-live-and-uncut/628192p1.html | title = GameSpy: Conker: Live and Reloaded | publisher = [[GameSpy]] | date = 22 June 2005 | first = Bryn | last = Williams}} The game was named IGN's "Best of E3 2005" in the category of "Best Graphics" for Xbox.[http://xbox.ign.com/articles/619/619567p1.html Xbox Best of E3 2005 Awards] However it was criticized for changes to the singleplayer campaign compared to the original, such as the removal of certain challenges, and the lack of refinement in areas such as facial animation that was perfected on the Nintendo 64. IGN didn't find the new multiplayer to be as fun as the original.{{cite web | url = http://www.ign.com/articles/2005/06/17/conker-live-and-reloaded | title = Conker: Live and Reloaded | publisher = [[IGN]] | accessdate = 3 January 2014 | date = 17 June 2005 | first = Hilary | last = Goldstein}} The multiplayer mode (new in this version of the game) remained popular well into 2007 (over a year and a half since its release) when it remained in the top 10 most played online titles for its platform.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080107034847/http://209.11.233.28/archive/2008/01/04/top-xbox-live-games-of-2007.aspx Lary 'Major Nelson' Hryb, Top Xbox LIVE Games of 2007 (Retrieved from the Internet Archive.)] ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'' gave it a perfect ten and stated that, "up to 16 people can torch each other. It's more of everything you loved (and decent people protested)."{{cite web | url = http://www.maximonline.com/entertainment/reviews/review_games_10024.html | title = Conker: Live and Reloaded | publisher = ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]'' | accessdate = 3 January 2014 | date = 21 June 2005 | author = Maxim staff | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050701023803/http://www.maximonline.com/entertainment/reviews/review_games_10024.html | archivedate = 1 July 2005 | deadurl = yes}} ''[[The New York Times]]'' gave it a favorable review, stating, "The game is essentially a burlesque of every game featuring cute forest creatures. It has the sort of platform-jumping, rope-climbing, monster-whomping challenges seen in many of these games, but adds foulmouthed animals, scatological humor and gallons of vividly scarlet cartoon blood."{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2005/07/02/sports/othersports/02game.html?ex=1121054400&en=c235857bfda2f116&ei=5070&emc=eta1&_r=0 | title = That Drunken Red Squirrel Whomps Again | publisher = ''[[The New York Times]]'' | accessdate = 3 January 2014 | date = 2 July 2005 | first = Charles | last = Herold}} ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' gave it four stars out of five and said, "The potty humour will not be to everyone's taste but many films are hilariously lampooned." However, Jim Schaefer of ''[[Detroit Free Press]]'' gave it three stars out of four and said that he found it "amusing to relive some of Conker's bawdy behavior, but I wish they would have come up with a new story rather than remaking the old one." In Japan, ''[[Famitsu]]'' gave it a score of all four sevens, for a total of 28 out of 40. {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wikiquote}} * {{moby game|id=/conker-live-reloaded|name=''Conker: Live & Reloaded''}} {{Portal bar|2000s|Comedy|Video games}} {{Conker series}} {{Rare}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Conker: Live and Reloaded}} [[Category:2005 video games]] [[Category:3D platform games]] [[Category:Black comedy]] [[Category:Conker]] [[Category:Dinosaurs in video games]] [[Category:Microsoft games]] [[Category:Multiplayer online games]] [[Category:Multiplayer and single-player video games]] [[Category:Parody video games]] [[Category:Platform games]] [[Category:Rare (company) games]] [[Category:Vampire video games]] [[Category:Censored video games]] [[Category:Video game remakes]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video games scored by Robin Beanland]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:War video games]] [[Category:Xbox games]] [[Category:Xbox-only games]] [[Category:Zombie video games]]

{{use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Doris Kearns Goodwin | image = DIG13890-059.jpg | caption =Goodwin in May 2016 | alt = | birth_name = Doris Helen Kearns | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1943|01|04|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | residence = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | ethnicity = | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = | education = [[Colby College]] (B.A.)
[[Harvard University]] (Ph.D.) | alma_mater = | employer = | occupation = Historian, author, political commentator | years_active = 1977–present | home_town = | party = | opponents = | boards = | religion = | spouse = {{marriage|[[Richard N. Goodwin]]|1975|2018|end=(his death)}} | children = Richard, Michael and Joseph Goodwin | relatives = | website = {{url|doriskearnsgoodwin.com}} | footnotes = }} '''Doris Helen Kearns Goodwin''' (born January 4, 1943) is an American [[biographer]], [[historian]], and [[political commentator]]. Goodwin has written biographies of several U.S. presidents, including ''Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream''; ''The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys: An American Saga''; ''[[Team of Rivals|Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln]]''; and ''The Bully Pulpit: Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, and the Golden Age of Journalism''. Goodwin's book ''No Ordinary Time: Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt: The Home Front in World War II'' won the [[Pulitzer Prize for History]] in 1995. ==Early life and education== Doris Helen Kearns was born in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], the daughter of Helen Witt (''née'' Miller) and Michael Francis Aloysius Kearns. She has a sister, Jene Kearns.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=63nvmt4HqTEC&pg=PA323 |title=Who's who of Pulitzer Prize winners - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.ca |date= |accessdate= May 27, 2013|isbn=9781573561112 |year=1999 }}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LbvjR1-QjJkC&pg=PA131 |title=100 Most Popular Nonfiction Authors: Biographical Sketches and Bibliographies - Bernard Alger Drew - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.ca |date= |accessdate= May 27, 2013|isbn=9781591584872 |year=2008 }} Her paternal grandparents were Irish immigrants.{{cite web|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SL&p_theme=sl&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB086B0C51215E1&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D |title=STLtoday.com - Archive - News |publisher=Nl.newsbank.com |date= January 5, 1998 |accessdate= May 27, 2013}} She grew up in [[Rockville Centre, New York]]. She attended [[Colby College]] in [[Maine]], where she was a member of [[Delta Delta Delta]] and [[Phi Beta Kappa]], and was graduated ''[[magna cum laude]]'' in 1964 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree. She was awarded a [[Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation|Woodrow Wilson Fellowship]] in 1964{{cite web |accessdate = October 27, 2008 |url = http://www.woodrow.org/fellowships/about_fellows/arts_letters.php |title = About Our Fellows |publisher = Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100705205428/http://www.woodrow.org/fellowships/about_fellows/arts_letters.php |archivedate = July 5, 2010 |df = mdy-all }} to pursue doctoral studies. In 1968, she earned a [[Ph.D.]] in government from [[Harvard University]], with a thesis titled "Prayer and Reapportionment: An Analysis of the Relationship between the Congress and the Court."{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/search?q=no:76988853|title=Prayer and reapportionment; an analysis of the relationship between the Congress and the Court.|first=Doris Helen|last=Kearns|date=May 21, 1968|publisher=|via=Open WorldCat}} ==Career and awards== In 1967, Kearns went to [[Washington, D.C.]] as a [[White House Fellow]] during the [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] administration. Johnson initially expressed interest in hiring the young intern as his Oval Office assistant, but after an article by Kearns appeared in ''[[The New Republic]]'' laying out a scenario for Johnson's removal from office over his conduct of the [[Vietnam War|war in Vietnam]], she was instead assigned to the Department of Labor; Goodwin has written that she felt relieved to be able to remain in the internship program in any capacity at all. "The president discovered that I had been actively involved in the anti-Vietnam War movement and had written an article entitled, 'How to Dump Lyndon Johnson'. I thought for sure he would kick me out of the program, but instead he said, 'Oh, bring her down here for a year and if I can't win her over, no one can'."[http://www.dartmouth.edu/~news/releases/1998/june98/dkg.html "Dartmouth 1998 commencement address"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060206230551/http://www.dartmouth.edu/~news/releases/1998/june98/dkg.html |date=February 6, 2006 }}. [[Dartmouth College]]. Retrieved July 27, 2007. After Johnson decided not to run for reelection, he brought Kearns to the White House as a member of his staff, where she focused on domestic anti-poverty efforts.Lyndon B. Johnson and the American Dream, "Prologue" [[File:Doris Kearns Goodwin by Gage Skidmore 2.jpg|right|thumb|Kearns Goodwin at a "Dinner with Lincoln" event in November 2017]] After Johnson left office in 1969, Kearns taught government at [[Harvard University|Harvard]] for 10 years, including a course on the [[President of the United States|American presidency]]. During this period, she also assisted Johnson in drafting his [[memoir]]s. Her first book ''Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream'', which drew upon her conversations with the late president, was published in 1977, becoming a [[New York Times bestseller|''New York Times'' bestseller]] and provided a launching pad for her literary career. A sports journalist as well, Goodwin was the first female journalist to enter the [[Boston Red Sox]] locker room in 1979. She consulted on and appeared in [[Ken Burns]]'s 1994 documentary ''[[Baseball (documentary)|Baseball]]''. Goodwin won the 1995 [[Pulitzer Prize for History]] for ''[[No Ordinary Time|No Ordinary Time: Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt: The Home Front During World War II]]'' (1994).{{Cite book|asin=0684804484|title=Amazon.com: No Ordinary Time: Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt: The Home Front in World War II (9780684804484): Doris Kearns Goodwin: Books|work=amazon.com}} Goodwin received an honorary [[L.H.D.]] from [[Bates College]] in 1998.{{cite web|accessdate=|url=http://www.doriskearnsgoodwin.com/about.php|title=About the Author|publisher=Doris Kearns Goodwin|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015075526/http://www.doriskearnsgoodwin.com/about.php|archivedate=October 15, 2008|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|accessdate= |url=http://womenshistory.about.com/library/bio/blbiogoodwindk.htm |title=Doris Kearns Goodwin (January 4, 1943– ) – Biographer; Assistant to President Lyndon Johnson |work=Women's History|publisher=[[about.com]]}} {{cite web|accessdate=|url=http://smithsonianassociates.org/programs/goodwin/goodwin.asp|title=Doris Kearns Goodwin: History, Baseball, and the Art of the Narrative|date=October 20, 1997|publisher=Smithsonian Associates|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060411192440/http://smithsonianassociates.org/programs/goodwin/goodwin.asp|archivedate=April 11, 2006|df=mdy-all}} {{cite web|accessdate= |url=http://gos.sbc.edu/g/goodwin.html |title= 109th Landon Lecture |author=Goodwin, Doris Kearns |work=109th Landon Lecture |publisher=Landon Lecture Series at Kansas State University |date=April 22, 1997}}{{cite web |accessdate = |url = http://www.dartmouth.edu/~news/releases/1998/june98/dkg.html |author = Goodwin, Doris Kearns |title = Commencement address at Dartmouth College |date = June 14, 1998 |work = Dartmouth News |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20060206230551/http://www.dartmouth.edu/~news/releases/1998/june98/dkg.html |archive-date = February 6, 2006 |dead-url = yes |df = mdy-all }} {{cite web|accessdate= |url=http://drucker.org/leaderbooks/l2l/summer98/goodwin.html |title= Lessons of Presidential Leadership |author=Goodwin, Doris Kearns |work=Leader to Leader |date=Summer 1998 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060302112739/http://www.drucker.org/leaderbooks/l2l/summer98/goodwin.html |archivedate=2006-03-02}} She was awarded an honorary doctorate from [[Westfield State College]] in 2008. Goodwin was on air talking to [[Tom Brokaw]] of [[NBC News]] during their [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 Presidential Election Night]] Coverage where Brokaw made his announcement that NBC had in fact projected the state of [[United States presidential election in Florida, 2000|Florida]] for [[George W. Bush]] making him president.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOaaUackKFQ|title=Election 2000 Florida, Florida, Florida|first=|last=Jim Heath|date=November 12, 2011|publisher=|via=YouTube}} Goodwin won the 2005 [[Lincoln Prize]] (for the best book about the [[American Civil War]]) for ''[[Team of Rivals|Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln]]'' (2005), a book about [[Abraham Lincoln]]'s [[presidential cabinet]]. Part of the book was adapted by [[Tony Kushner]] into the screenplay for [[Steven Spielberg]]'s 2012 film ''[[Lincoln (2012 film)|Lincoln]]''. She is a member of the [[Abraham Lincoln Bicentennial Commission]] advisory board.[https://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=2656145181816205925 National Constitution Center talk] at [[Google Videos]] November 2, 2005 (skip to 30 minute mark) {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070225063946/https://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=2656145181816205925 |date=February 25, 2007 }}[http://www.lawac.org/speech/2005-2006/GOODWIN,%20Doris%202005.pdf Address] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060306075304/http://www.lawac.org/speech/2005-2006/GOODWIN%2C%20Doris%202005.pdf |date=March 6, 2006 }} to the Los Angeles [[World Affairs Councils of America|World Affairs Council]] November 15, 2005[http://www.cityarts.net/n.kearns.goodwin.html City Arts and Lectures appearance] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060203043246/http://www.cityarts.net/n.kearns.goodwin.html |date=February 3, 2006 }} November 16, 2005{{cite web|url=http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=7696201515014282285 |title=Team of Rivals: The Political Genius of Abraham Lincoln |publisher=Books of Our Time |date= |accessdate=February 10, 2012}} The book also won the inaugural [[American History Book Prize]] given by the [[New-York Historical Society]]. [[File:Doris Kearns Goodwin (11131).jpg|thumb|Kearns Goodwin signing copies of ''Leadership in Turbulent Times'' at [[BookExpo America]] in 2018]] Goodwin was a member of the [[board of directors]] for [[Northwest Airlines]]. Goodwin is a frequent guest commentator on ''[[Meet the Press]]'', appearing many times (during the tenures of hosts [[Tim Russert]], [[Tom Brokaw]], [[David Gregory (journalist)|David Gregory]], and [[Chuck Todd]]), as well as a regular guest on ''[[Charlie Rose (TV series)|Charlie Rose]]'', appearing a total of forty-eight times since 1994. [[Stephen King]] met with Goodwin while he was writing his novel ''[[11/22/63]]'', due to her being an assistant to Johnson, and King used some of her ideas in the novel on what a worst-case scenario would be like if history had changed.Alter, Alexandra (October 28, 2011). [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204644504576651540980143566 "Stephen King's New Monster"]. ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''. [[File:Doris Kearns Goodwin 2018.jpg|thumb|Kearns Goodwin at the LBJ Presidential Library in 2018]] In 2014, Kearns won the [[Andrew Carnegie Medal for Excellence in Nonfiction]] for ''The Bully Pulpit''.{{cite web |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/books/2023957398_apxbookscarnegiemedals.html |title=Tartt, Goodwin awarded Carnegie medals |work=Seattle Times |agency=Associated Press |author=Hillel Italie |date=June 30, 2014 |accessdate=July 1, 2014}} It was also a [[Los Angeles Times Book Prize]] finalist (History, 2013){{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2014/feb/19/entertainment/la-et-jc-announcing-the-la-times-book-prize-finalists-for-2013-20140219 |title=Announcing the L.A. Times Book Prize finalists for 2013 |work=[[LA Times]] |author=Carolyn Kellogg |date=February 19, 2014 |accessdate=April 14, 2014}} and a ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'' 15 best nonfiction (2013).{{citation needed|date=July 2014}} In 2016, she appeared as herself in the [[Chapter 5 (American Horror Story)|fifth episode]] of ''[[American Horror Story: Roanoke]]''.{{cite web|last1=Stephens|first1=Emily L.|title=AHS: Roanoke finds itself in a hole, keeps digging—into its past|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/ahs-roanoke-finds-itself-hole-keeps-digging-its-pa-244095|accessdate=14 October 2016|date=13 October 2016}} ===Plagiarism controversy=== In 2002, ''[[The Weekly Standard]]'' determined that her book ''The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys'' used without attribution numerous phrases and sentences from three other books: ''Times to Remember,'' by [[Rose Kennedy]]; ''The Lost Prince,'' by Hank Searl; and ''[[Kathleen Cavendish, Marchioness of Hartington|Kathleen Kennedy]]: Her Life and Times,'' by [[Lynne McTaggart]].Crader, Bo (January 28, 2002). [https://www.weeklystandard.com/a-historian-and-her-sources/article/2088 "A Historian and Her Sources"]. ''The Weekly Standard''. McTaggart remarked, "If somebody takes a third of somebody's book, which is what happened to me, they are lifting out the heart and guts of somebody else's individual expression."Lawless, Jill (March 23, 2002). [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1980&dat=20020324&id=fAMuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uakFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2912,3165716 "Author Says Doris Kearns Goodwin Took 'Heart and Guts' From Her Book"]. [[Associated Press]]. Goodwin had previously reached a "private settlement" with McTaggart over the issue. In an article she wrote for ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine, she said, "Though my footnotes repeatedly cited Ms. McTaggart's work, I failed to provide quotation marks for phrases that I had taken verbatim... The larger question for those of us who write history is to understand how citation mistakes can happen."{{Cite journal |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,197614,00.html|first=Doris Kearns|last= Goodwin|title=How I Caused That Story |journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=January 27, 2002}} In its analysis of the controversy, [[Slate (magazine)|''Slate'' magazine]] criticized Goodwin for the aggrieved tone of her explanation, and suggested Goodwin's worst offense was allowing the plagiarism to remain in future editions of the book even after it was brought to her attention.{{cite web|last1=Noah|first1=Timothy|title=How To Curb the Plagiarism Epidemic|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/chatterbox/2002/01/how_to_curb_the_plagiarism_epidemic.html|publisher=Slate Magazine|accessdate=6 October 2017|date=28 January 2002|df=mdy-all}} ''Slate'' also reported that there were multiple passages in Goodwin's book on the Roosevelts (''No Ordinary Time'') that were apparently taken from [[Joseph P. Lash|Joseph Lash]]'s ''Eleanor and Franklin'', Hugh Gregory Gallagher's ''FDR's Splendid Deception,'' and other books, although she "scrupulously" footnoted the material. The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' reported similar circumstances concerning her book ''The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys''.King, Peter H. (August 4, 2002). [http://articles.latimes.com/2002/aug/04/nation/na-goodwin4 "As History Repeats Itself, the Scholar Becomes the Story"]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''.{{cite journal |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2091197/|first=Timothy |last=Noah |authorlink=Timothy Noah|title=Historians Rewrite History: The Campaign to Exonerate Doris Kearns Goodwin|journal=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=November 13, 2003}} The allegations of plagiarism caused Goodwin to resign from the [[Pulitzer Prize]] Board{{Cite web |title=Doris Kearns Goodwin Leaves Pulitzer Prize Board |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=2002-05-31 |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB102286350955910280 |accessdate=2018-04-15 |df=mdy-all |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20180415152507/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB102286350955910280 |archivedate=April 15, 2018 |deadurl=no }} and her position as a regular guest on the ''[[PBS NewsHour]]'' program.{{cite web|first=Mark |last=Lewis |url=https://www.forbes.com/2002/02/27/0227goodwin.html |title=Doris Kearns Goodwin And The Credibility Gap | work = [[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]] |date=February 27, 2002 |accessdate=February 10, 2012}} ==Personal life== In 1975, Kearns married [[Richard N. Goodwin]],{{cite news | url = http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ME&p_theme=me&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAE9A2207EC4633&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D | title = The Natural TV producers love Doris Kearns Goodwin, historian and baseball fan, who is right at home in front of a camera. Now Mainers will have three chances to see her in person | last = Roughier | first = Ray | work = [[Portland Press Herald]] | page = 1C | date = March 15, 1995 | accessdate = September 6, 2009}} who had worked in the Kennedy and Johnson administrations as an adviser and speechwriter. The two met in mid-1972 at [[Harvard's Institute of Politics]].{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kOkCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA41&lpg=PA41#v=onepage&q=richard+goodwin+son+sandra|title=New York|first=New York Media|last=LLC|date=August 18, 1975|publisher=New York Media, LLC|via=Google Books}} Richard Goodwin had a son, also named Richard, from a previous marriage, who was nine years old at the time he and Kearns married.{{cite web|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1975/12/15/doris-kearns-and-richard-goodwin-marry/|title=Doris Kearns and Richard Goodwin Marry, As Kennedy, Mailer and White Spectate – News – The Harvard Crimson|website=www.thecrimson.com}} Goodwin and Kearns Goodwin, who lived in [[Concord, Massachusetts]], also had two sons together, Michael and Joseph.{{cite web|url=http://www.richardngoodwin.com/about.html|title=About – The Official Richard N. Goodwin Website|first=David Cosgrove Los Angeles Web|last=Design|website=www.richardngoodwin.com}} Her husband died on May 20, 2018, after a brief battle with cancer.{{cite web|url=https://wtop.com/national/2018/05/richard-n-goodwin-white-house-speech-writer-dead-at-86/|title=Richard N. Goodwin, White House speech writer, dead at 86|date=May 21, 2018|publisher=}} Growing up in [[Long Island]], Goodwin was a fan of the [[Brooklyn Dodgers]]. She noted that her father would have her document the baseball game from the radio and replay the events of the game once he returned home. Goodwin stopped following baseball after the Dodgers moved to [[Los Angeles]] in 1957, but later became a [[Boston Red Sox]] fan while attending Harvard, and is now a [[season ticket]] holder. https://player.fm/series/larry-wilmore-black-on-the-air/historian-doris-kearns-goodwin-looks-to-the-presidents-of-the-past-to-understand-the-politics-of-today-larry-wilmore-ep54 ==Bibliography== * {{cite book|title=Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream|year=1977|isbn=0060122846|oclc=429528985}}{{Cite book|asin=0312060270|title=Amazon.com: Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream: The Most Revealing Portrait of a President and Presidential Power Ever Written (9780312060275): Doris Kearns Goodwin: Books|work=amazon.com}} * {{cite book|title=The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys: An American Saga|year=1987|isbn=9780312909338|oclc=731388852}}{{Cite book|asin=0312063547|title=The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys : An American Saga: Doris Kearns Goodwin: 9780312063542: Amazon.com: Books|work=amazon.com}} * {{cite book|title=[[No Ordinary Time|No Ordinary Time: Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt: The Home Front in World War II]]|year=1994|isbn=978-0-671-64240-2}} * {{cite book|title=Wait Till Next Year: A Memoir|year=1997|isbn=0684824892|oclc=37567424}}{{Cite book|asin=0684847957|title=Wait Till Next Year - The '''Triennial E. A. Lowe Lectures''' are an ongoing series of lectures held at [[Corpus Christi College, Oxford|Corpus Christi College]], [[University of Oxford]], in memory of the noted palaeographer [[Elias Avery Lowe|E. A. Lowe]] who was an [[Honorary title (academic)|Honorary Fellow]] of the College from 1954 until his death in 1969. They are delivered by prominent [[Palaeography|palaeographers]], with each scholar giving a trio of lectures on a topic within the field.<ref name=Jonge>{{cite web |title=Erik Kwakkel Becomes 2014 E.A. Lowe Lecturer in Oxford |publisher=De Jonge Akademie |date=5 Nov 2012 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=https://www.dejongeakademie.nl/en/nieuws/erik-kwakkel-e-a-lowe-lecturer-oxford}}</ref> Oxford University Press sometimes publishes revised versions of the lectures. Lecturers have included N. G. Wilson, [[A. C. de la Mare]], Anthony Grafton, and Michael Lapidge.<ref name=CCCLect>{{cite web |title=Special Lectures |publisher=Corpus Christi College, Oxford University |date=2016 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=https://www.ccc.ox.ac.uk/Special-Lectures/}}</ref><ref name=Leiden>{{cite web |title=Erik Kwakkel to hold the 2014 E. A. Lowe Lectures in Corpus Christi College, Oxford |publisher=Turning Over a New Leaf, Universiteit Leiden |date=17 Jan 2014 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=http://www.hum.leiden.edu/lucas/turning-over-a-new-leaf/news/lowelectures.html}}</ref>
